summary: This is a July 4, 2019, internal briefing memo from a prosecutor in the Southern District of New York outlining the strategy for approaching key individuals following Jeffrey Epstein's arrest. It details the charges against Epstein, provides a criminal conduct overview, and lists specific individuals to be approached, including Ghislaine Maxwell, Jean-Luc Brunel, and Les Wexner, with tailored talking points and legal precautions.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central defendant, charged with sex trafficking of minor girls and conspiracy. The memo details his modus operandi of paying underage girls for massages that escalated into sexual acts.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Described as Epstein's girlfriend for many years, believed to have assisted in recruiting victims, traveled extensively with him, and is a subject of the investigation to be approached with a subpoena.

persons.name: Jean-Luc Brunel
persons.context: A former close friend and associate of Epstein who had a falling out. Reported to have recruited minors for sexual activity with Epstein through his modeling agency and is a subject of the investigation.

persons.name: Les Wexner
persons.role: Long-time friend and business associate of Epstein
persons.context: A billionaire founder of The Limited, described as having a decades-long business relationship with Epstein. He is to be approached, but the memo expects he will likely just receive a subpoena.

persons.name: Heidi Fleiss
persons.context: Mentioned as a figure one subject (name redacted) compared herself to, in the context of recruiting.

persons.name: Leslie Groff
persons.context: Listed as an individual requiring special legal precautions during the approach, indicating they are a subject of the investigation.

connections.description: Described as Epstein's girlfriend for many years and an associate who traveled extensively with him and allegedly assisted in recruiting victims.
Described as a former close friend and associate who reportedly recruited minors for sexual activity with Epstein. They later had a falling out and were engaged in litigation.
Described as having a decades-long business relationship with Epstein.
The memo states Maxwell is reported to have had a sexual relationship with him and/or with certain underage girls, implicating her in the abuse scheme.

events.title: Prosecutor Briefing on Approach Strategy
events.description: A prosecutor in the Southern District of New York circulates a detailed memo outlining the strategy for approaching key subjects and witnesses following Jeffrey Epstein's arrest.

events.title: Arrest of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein has been arrested and charged in the Southern District of New York with sex trafficking of minor girls and conspiracy.

events.title: Prior Florida Investigation and NPA
events.description: Reference to Epstein's prior investigation by the U.S. Attorney's Office and FBI in Florida, which led to a non-prosecution agreement (NPA). The memo clarifies this NPA does not apply to the SDNY case.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was charged with sex trafficking of minors and conspiracy in the Southern District of New York, facing up to 45 years in prison, for conduct in New York and Florida.
The memo explicitly states that any prior non-prosecution agreement from Florida does not apply to the SDNY prosecution, countering potential immunity claims.
Ghislaine Maxwell, Jean-Luc Brunel, and Les Wexner are identified as key individuals to be approached, with Maxwell and Brunel specifically implicated in victim recruitment.
The document reveals investigative details, including that Epstein used victims as recruiters, paid in cash, and that schedulers (employees) booked 'massages' with underage girls.
Special legal precautions are mandated for approaching Leslie Groff, Ghislaine Maxwell, and another redacted individual, indicating they may already have legal representation connected to the case.
